titlePage.docImprint: Vol. Xxiv — no.34 Richmond, Va. Monday, February 9, 1863 Price one Cent

div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at six and A Quarter Cents Per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: Another Brilliant Feat in Texas.
div3.p: A telegraphic dispatch from Gen. Magruder to the Secretary of War, received last Saturday night, says that Major O. M. Watkins, in command of the expedition against the enemy at Sabine Pass, reports that he captured "thirteen guns, property worth a million of dollars, and 109 prisoners." Our rams were at sea, off the Sabine Pass, "waiting for new commerce."

div3.head: Dead
div3.p:
--Hon. Henry L. Pinkney, the founder of the Charleston Mercury, died in that city on the 3d inst. He was formerly a member of the U. States Congress from that district.
It was his father who submitted the "Constitution of the United States" to the Congress of 1787, the larger portion of which was adopted.
Hon. Wm. Elliott, another prominent South Carolinian, is dead.

div3.head: Lucky Hall.
div3.p: --A few days since Capt. McNeil's partisan rangers captured a lot of Yankee stores in Hardy county, Va., which were sold for $29,000, which was divided among the captors.

div4.p: --The Senate met at 12 o'clock. Prayer by Rev. Dr. J. C. McCabe.
A communication from the Executive, in response to a resolution of the Senate calling for information in regard to the State Line, was laid upon the table and ordered to be printed.

Resolutions of Inquiry.--By Mr. Nash, on instructing the Committee on Banks to inquire into the expediency of extending the operation of the law passed March 1, 1862, legalizing the suspension of specie payments by the banks of the State; by Mr. Marshall of the expediency of appointing a geologist and mining engineer for the State whose duty it shall be to explore the material resources of Virginia; by Mr. Ball, on amending the stay law so as to enable securities to relieve themselves from their liabilities as such securities.

A bill to amend the first, third, fourth, and seventh sections of an "Act to provide for the public defence," passed October 3d, 1862, was, after being amended and discussed at some length, and considerable progress being made therein, passed over until Monday.
On motion of Mr. Christian, of Augusta, the Senate adjourned.
[Quite a scene occurred in the gallery, caused by a poor fellow — a soldier — being taken with an epileptic fit, which created quite a sensation, amid which the Senate adjourned.]

div4.head: House of Delegates.
div4.p:
--The House met at the usual hour.
Prayer by Rev. Dr. Reid.
A resolution was submitted by Mr. Rives, and agreed to calling upon the Governor to inform the House what amount of the appropriation made for the Lunatic Asylum at Williamsburg has been used, &c.
On motion of Mr. James the rules were suspended, and the bill changing the time of holding the Circuit Courts in the 14th Judicial District, was read a third time and passed.
On motion of Mr. Harrison, the calendar was read, and the bill amending the Code so as to allow but one Major to each regiment, was passed.

On motion of Mr. Anderson of Rockbridge, the House resumed the consideration of the pending question — the extortion bill — and that gentleman being entitled to the floor, addressed the House in favor of his substitute reported the previous day.
Mr. Wilson, of Isle of Wight, opposed the bill.--The thread of his remarks, however, was cut short by the falling of the Speaker's hammer at the expiration of ten minutes.
Mr. Anderson, of Botetourt, obtained the floor for ten minutes, at which time.

Mr. James moved to rescind the order for closing debate at 2 o'clock, upon which Mr. Forbes demanded the ayes and noes.
The vote stood — ayes 33, noes 64.

The hour of 2 o'clock having now arrived, the Speaker announced that the vote would be taken on the motion of Mr. Anderson, of Rockbridge, to strike out of the amended substitute all after the fourth section.
Mr. Harrison called for the ayes and noes, which resulted — ayes 45, noes 53.
The House having refused to strike out, the question then came up on striking out from the original bill all after the words "Be it enacted by the General Assembly," &c.
The ayes and noes were called for by Mr. Wilson, of Isle of Wight, and stood — ayes 53, noes 33.

The original bill having been defeated, the vote was then taken upon inserting the amended substitute, upon which Mr. West called for the ayes and noes.
The following is the vote:

Ayes.--John T. Anderson, Bass, Bayse, Bigger, Booton, Crockett, Daniel, Dunn, Eggleston, Ewing, Fleming, Fletcher, Franklin, Gatewood, George, Henry L. Hopkins, Huntt, James, Johnson, Kaufman, Kyle, Laidly, Lively, Lockridge, McCamant, Isaac E. McDonald, McLaughlin Montague, Pitman, Powell, Richardson, Rives, Robinson, Rowan, Staples, F. G. Taylor, Thomas, Treadway, Vermillion, Walker, Woodhouse, Worsham--42.

Nays--H. W. Sheffey, Speaker; Francis T. Anderson, Baskerville, Baily, Baker, Bouldin, Bradford, Buford, Burks, Cazenove, Clarke, Coffman Coleman, Davis, Evans, Forbes, Fry, Fulton, Gilmer, Grattan, Greene, Harrison, John H. Hopkins Hunter, Jones, Jordan, Magruder, Hallory, Morye, Mayo, A. W. McDonald, R. E. Nelson, W. G. T. Nelson, Newton, Noland, Orgain, Reid, Robertson, Rutherford, Peter Saunders, R. C. Saunders, Sherrard, R. F. Taylor, Thrash, Tomlin, Tyler, Ward, West, Williams James L. Wilson, Samuel M. Wilson and Wyune--52.
The bill having been defeated, Mr. Anderson, of Rockbridge, moved to recommit the whole subject to the Committee on Extortion, which was agreed to.
On motion of Mr. Lockridge, the House adjourned.
--The Senate having adjourned over on Friday till Monday, was not in session to-day.

div4.head: House of representatives.
div4.p: --The House met at 12 o'clock, and was opened with prayer.
Mr. Miles, of S. C., submitted several papers, which, without being read, were laid upon the table and ordered to be printed.

Mr. Chilton, of Ala., from the Committee on Commissary and Quartermasters' Departments, reported a bill to prevent frauds in those departments, and the obtaining under false pretences transportation for private property.
Ordered to be printed.
Mr. Hoicombe, of Va., moved a suspension of the rules, with a view to take up the impressment bill introduced by him several days ago, but the motion did not prevail.
Mr. Gartrell, of Ga., presented the memorial of Brown, Fleming & Co., of Atlanta, Ga., for sugar seized by the Government; which was referred to the Committee on Claims.
Mr. Foote, of Tenn., moved to go into secret session on the important business of yesterday, which was agreed to by a vote of 41 to 36, and the House went into secret session.

div3.head: Removal of the British Consul at Charleston.
div3.p:
--Mr. Robt Bunch, H. B. M. Consul at Charleston, S. C., has, it appears, been removed from that post and ordered to England, not to Havana, to avoid the danger of a bombardment as was stated.
He had been Consul at Charleston for ten years and was very popular with its citizens.
Henry P. Walker, the Vice-Consul, will act until another Consul is appointed.
The Mercury, speaking of Mr. Bunch's recall, says:

q.p:
For fifteen months, or since the Muir business, the exequatur of Mr. Robert Bunch from the United States Government has been withdrawn.
He has been the Consular Agent of her Britannic Majesty at this port, and is now permanently withdrawn by his Government.
We learn that, both from the British Minister to the U. S. Lord Lyons, and from his Government itself, he has assurances that his course in Charleston is approved, with the promise of promotion to a more important diplomatic post.
It is said that under the prospect of a formidable attack on Charleston, it would not be proper to expose the obnoxious Mr. Bunch, deprived of his official position, to the hostility of the Yankee forces, should they succeed; therefore, the Cadmus has been sent to remove him out of the way of any such unpleasantness.
It seems more probable, however, that the real motive of his withdrawal is a desire on the part of Lord Lyons and of the British Administration to gratify the United States Government in the removal of Mr. Bunch, whose views and course has been more unprejudiced and just to the Confederate States than their own. Yet, while proceeding to do so, it accords with British custom to avoid sacrificing an officer who has done his best for his country, and at the same time, also to avoid, as far as practionable, the appearance to the Confederate States of removing an officer because of his fairness and supposed friendly bias.
The danger to Mr. Bunch of remaining longer in Charleston may be a mere diplomatic reason on the part of Lord Lyons for his immediate transfer to London.

div3.head: More reported disaffection among the Yankees.
div3.p: --The Kinston correspondent of the Raleigh State Journal, under date of February 2d, writes:

q.p:
Three Abolition deserters came into our lines to Capt. Whitford's pickets on yesterday.
They say that great dissatisfaction exists amongst the Federal troops at New and city.
The 28th New York regiment at Morehead City on Thursday, refusing to fight another day until they were paid off. Three regiments were immediately dispatched from Newburn to Morehead to quilt the rebellion, but they had accomplished nothing at the last accounts.
The mutiny was still railing to a fearful extent.

div3.p:
Transports and gunboats continue to leave Newburn for parts unknown.
The 97th sail of Yankee vessels were seen off the mouth of New river on Saturday last, headed southward.

div3.head: A correspondent on America.
div3.p:
Two rival publishing houses in Boston and New York have published simultaneously "My Diary North and South," by Wm. Howard Russell, the war correspondent of the London Times.
We make two extracts:

div4.head: A State dinner at Lincoln's White House.
div4.p:
In the evening I repaired to the White House.
The servant who took my hat and coat was particularly inquisitive as to my name and condition in life, and when he heard I was not a minister he seemed inclined to question my right to be there at all; "for," said he, "there are none but members of the Cabinet and their wives and daughters dining here to-day." Eventually he relaxed, instructed me how to place my hat so that it would be exposed to no indignity, and informed me that I was about to participate in a prandial enjoyment of no ordinary character.
There was no parade or display, no announcement — no glided staircase, with its liverled heralds, transmitting and translating one's name from landing to landing.
From the unpretending ante chamber a walk across the lofty hall led us to the reception room, which was the same as that in which the President held his interview yesterday.

Mrs. Lincoln was already seated to receive her guests.
She is of the middle age and bright, of a plumpness degenerating to the embonpoint natural to her ears; her features are plain, her nose and mouth of an ordinary type, and her manners and appearance homely, stiffened, however, by the communicates that her position required her to be something more than plain Mrs. Lincoln, the wife of the Illinois lawyer; she is profuse in the introduction of the word "air" in every sentence, which is now almost an Americanism confined to certain classes, although it was once as common in England.
Her dress I shall not attempt to describe, though it was very gorgeous and highly colored.
She handled a fan with much energy, displaying a round, well-proportioned arm, and was adorned with some simple jewelry.
Mrs. Lincoln struck me as being desirous of making herself agreeable; and I own I was agreeably disappointed, as the secessionist ladies at Washington had been amusing themselves by anecdotes which could scarcely have been founded on fact.

Several of the ministers had already arrived; by and by all had come, and the party only waited for General Scott, who seemed to be the representative man in Washington of the monarchial idea, and to absorb some of the feeling which is lavished on the pictures and memory, if not on the monument, of Washington.
White we were waiting, Mr. Seward took me round and introduced me to the ministers, and to their wives and daughters.
Among the latter Miss.
Chase, who is very attractive, agreeable, and sprightly.
Her father, the finance minister, struck me as one of the most intelligent and distinguished persons in the whole assemblage; tall, of a good presence, with a well formed head a fine forehead, and a face indicating energy and power.
There is a peculiar droop and motion of the lid of one eye — which seems to have suffered from some injury — that detracts from the agreeable effect of his face; but, on the whole, he is one who would not pass quite unnoticed in a European crowd of the same description.

In the whole assemblage there was not a scrap of lace or a piece of ribbon, except the gorgeous epaufeites of an old naval officer who had served against us in the last war, and who represented some branch of the naval department.
Nor were the Ministers by any means remarkable for their personal appearance.

Mr. Cameron, the Secretary for War, a slight man, above the middle height, with grey hair, deep set keen gray eyes, and a thin mouth, gave me the idea of a person of ability and adroitness.
His colleague, the Secretary of the Navy, a small man, with a great long gray board and spectacles, did not look like one of much originality or ability; but people who know Mr. Welles declare that he is possessed of administrative power, although they admit that he does not know the stem from the stern of a ship, and are in doubt whether he ever saw the sea in his life.
Mr. Smith, the Minister of the Interior, is a bright eyed, smart (I use the word in the English sense) gentleman, with the reputation of being one of the most conservative members of the Cabinet--Mr. Blair, the Postmaster General, is a person of much greater influence than his position would indicate.
He has the reputation of being one of the most determined Republicans in the ministry; but he held peculiar notions with reference to the black and the white races, which, if carried out, would not by any means conduce to the comfort or happiness of free negroes in the United States.
He is a tall, lean man, with a hard, Scotch, practical-looking head — an anvil for ideas to be hammered on. His eyes are small and deeply act, and have a ratlike expression; and he speaks, with caution, as though he weighed every word before he uttered it. The last of the ministers is Mr. Bates, a stout, thick-set, common-looking man, with a large beard, who fills the office of Attorney General.--Some of the gentlemen were in evening dress, others wore black frock coats, which it seems, as in Turkey, are considered to be en regle at a Republican ministerial dinner.

In the conversation which occurred before dinner I was amused to observe the manner in which Mr. Lincoln used the anecdotes for which he is famous.
Where men bred in courts, accustomed to the world, or versed in diplomacy, would use some subterfuge, or would make a polite speech or give a shrug of the shoulders as the means of getting out of an embarrassing position, Mr. Lincoln raises a laugh by some bold west-country anecdote, and moves off in the cloud of merriment produced by his joke.
Thus, when Mr. Bates was remonstrating apparently against the appointment of some indifferent lawyer to a place of judicial importance, the President interposed with, "Come, now, Bates, he's not half as bad as you think.
Besides that, I must tell you, he did me a good turn long ago. When I took to the law, I was going to court one morning, with some ten or twelve miles of bad road before me, and I had no horse.
The Judge overtook me in his wagon. 'Hollo, Lincoln!
Are you not going to the Court-House?
Come in and I'll give you a seat' Well, I got in, and the judge went on reading his papers.
Presently the wagon struck a stump on one side of the road; then it hopped off to the other.
I looked out and I saw the driver was jerking from side to side in his seat, so says I, 'Judge, I think your coachman has been taking a little drop too much this morning. ' 'Well, I declare, Lincoln,' said he, 'I should not much wonder if you are right, for he has nearly upset me half a dozen of times since starting.' So putting his head out of the window, he shouted, 'Why, you infernal scoundrel, you are drunk!
Upon which, pulling up his horse, and turning round with great gravity, the coachman said, 'By gorral that's the first rightful decision you have given for the last twelve month." Whilst the company were laughing, the President beat a quiet retreat from the neighborhood of the Attorney-General.

It was at last announced that Gen. Scott was unable to be present, and that, although actually in the house, he had been compelled to retire from indisposition and we moved into the banqueting hall.
The first "state dinner," as it is called of the President, was not remarkable for ostentation.
No liveried servants, no Persic splendor of ancient plate, or chefs d' auvre of art glittered round the board.
Vases of flowers decorated the table, combined with dishes in what may be asked the "Gallo-American" style with wines which owed their parentage to France, and their rearing and education to the United States which abound in cunning nurses for such productions.
The conversation was suited to the state dinner of a cabinet at which women and strangers were present.
I was seated next to Mr. Bates and the very agreeable and lively Secretary of the President Mr. Hay, and except when there was an attentive silence, caused by one of the President's stories, there was a Babel of small talk round the table, in which I was surprised to find a diversity of ascent almost as great as if a number of foreigners had been speaking English.
I omitted the name of Mr. Hamlin, the Vice-President, as well as those of less remarkable people who were present; but it would not be becoming to pass over a man distinguished for nothing so much as his persistent and unvarying adhesion to one political doctrine which has made him, in combination with the belief in his honesty, the occupant of a post which leads to the Presidency in event of any occurrence which may remove Mr. Lincoln.

After dinner the ladies and gentlemen retired to the drawing-room, and the circle was increased by the addition of several politicians.
I had an opportunity of conversing with some of the ministers.
If not with all, from time to time, and I was struck by the uniform tendency of their remarks in reference to the policy of Great Britain.
They seemed to think that England was bound by her anti-slavery antecedents to discourage to the utmost any attempts of the South to establish its independence on a basis of slavery, and to assume that they were the representatives of an active war of emancipation.
As the veteran Commodore Stewart passed the chair of the young lady to whom I was speaking, she said: "I suppose, Mr. Russell, you do not admire that officer?" "On the contrary," I said, "I think he is a very finelooking old man." "I don't mean that," she replied; "but you know he can't be very much liked by you because he fought so gallantly against you in the last war, as you must know." I had not the courage to confess ignorance of the Captain's antecedents.
There is a delusion among more than the fair American who spoke to me that we entertain in England the sort of feeling, morbid or wholesome as it may be, in reference to our reverses at New Orleans and elsewhere, that is attributed to Frenchmen respecting Waterloo.

div4.head: President Davis.
div4.p: Russell got an introduction to President Davis, who did not, like Lincoln, invite him to dinner:

I had an opportunity of observing the President very closely.
He did not impress me as favorably as I had expected though he is certainly a very different looking man from Mr. Lincoln.
He is like a gentleman — has a sight, light figure, little exceeding middle a height, and holds himself erect and straight.
He was freshed in a reserved and drastic, his head a well formed, with a fine, full forehead, square and light, covered with innumerable fine lines and wrinkles, features regular, though the check hours are too high and the laws too hollow to be handsome; the lips are this, flexible, and coved the chin square, well defined the note very regular, with wide nostrills; and the eyes adeep act, large, and full--one seems nearly blind, and is partly covered with a film, owing to excruciating attacks of neuralgia and tic. Wonderful to relate, he does not chew, and is neat and clean-looking, with hair trimmed and boots brushed.
The expression of the face is anxious; he has a very haggard, care worn and pain-drawn look, though no trace of anything but the utmost confidence and the greatest decision could be detected in his conversation.
He asked me some questions respecting the route!
I had taken in the States.

I mentioned that I had seen great military preparations through the South, and was astonished at the alacrity with which the people sprang to arms-"Yes sir." he remarked, and his tone of voice and manner of speech are rather remarkable for what are considered Yankee peculiarities "In Europe," (Mr. Seward also indulges in that pronunciation,) 'they laugh at us because of our fondness for military titles and desplays.
All your travellers in this country have commented on the number of generals colonels, and majors all over the States.
But the fact is, we are a military people, and those signs of the fact were ignored.
We are not less military because we have had no great standing armies.
But perhaps we are the only people in the world where gentlemen go to a military academy who do not intend to follow the profession of arms."

In the course of the conversation I asked him to have the goodness to direct that a sort of passport or protection should be given me as I might possibly fall in with some guerrilla leader on my way northwards, in whose eyes I might not be entitled to safe conduct.
Mr. Davis said, "I shall give such instructions to the Secretary of War as shall be necessary.
But, r you are among civilized intelligent people, who understand your position, and appreciate your character.
We do not seek the sympathy of England by unworthy means, for we respect of ourselves, and we are glad to invite the scrutiny of men into our acts; as for our motives, we meet the eye of Heaven." I thought I could judge from his words that he had the highest idea of the French as soldiers, but that his feelings and associations were more identified with England, although he was quite aware of the difficulty of conquering the repugnance which exists to slavery.

Mr. Davis made no allusion to the authorities at Washington, but he asked me if I thought it was supposed in England there would be war between the two States?
I answered that I was under the impression the public thought there would be no actual hostilities. "And yet you see we are driven to take up arms for the defence of our rights and liberties."

div4.head: Secretary Seward.
div4.p:
24th.
I dined at Mr. Sanford's, where I was introduced to Mr. Seward, Secretary of State; Mr. Truman Smith, an ex-Senator, much respected among the Republican party; Mr. Antony, a Senator of the United States, a journalist, a very intelligent-looking man, with an Israelitish cast of face; Colonel Foster, of the Illinois railway, of reputation in the States as a geologist; and one or two more gentlemen.
Mr. Seward is a slight, middle-sized man, of feeble build, with the stoop contracted from sedentary habits and application to his desk, and has a peculiar attitude when seated, which immediately attracts attention.
A well-formed and large head is placed on a long, slender neck, and projects over the chest in an argumentative kind of way, as if the keen eyes were seeking for an adversary; the mouth is remarkably flexible, large but wellformed, the nose prominent and aquiline, the eyes secret but penetrating and lively, with humor of some kind twinkling about them; the brow bold and broad, but not remarkably elevated; the the white hair silvery and fine — a subtle, quick man, rejoining in power, given to perorate and to oracular utterances, fond of badinage, bursting with the importance of state mysteries, and with the dignity of directing the foreign policy of the greatest country — as all Americans think — in the world.--After dinner he told some stories of the pressure on the President, for place, which very much amused the guests who knew the men, and talked freely and pleasantly of many things, stating, however, few facts positively.
In reference to an assertion in a New York paper that orders had been given to evacuate Sumter. "That," he said "is a plain lie — no such orders have been given" We will give us nothing we have — abandon nothing that has been entrusted to us. If people would only read these statements by the fight of the President's inaugural they would not be deceived." He wanted no extra session of Congress. "History tells us that kings who call extra parliaments lose their heads," and he informed the company he had impressed the President with his historical parallels.

All through this conversation his tone was that of a man very sanguine, and with a supreme contempt for those who thought there was anything serious in secession. "Why," said he, "I myself, my brothers, and sisters, have been all Secessionists — we seceded from home when we were young, but we all went back to it sooner or later.
These States will all come back in the same way." I doubt if he was ever in the South; but he affirmed that the state of living and of society there was something like that in the State of New York sixty or seventy years ago. In the North all was life, enterprise, industry, mechanical skill.
In the South there was dependence on black labor, and an idle extravagance which was mistaken for elegant luxury — tumble down old hackney coaches, such as had not been seen north of the Potomac for half a century, harness never cleaned, ungroomed horses, worked at the mill one day and sent to town the next, badly furnished houses, bad cookery imperfect education.
No parallel could be drawn between them and the Northern States at all. "You are all very angry," he said "about the Morrill tariff.
You must, however, let us be the best judges of our own affairs.
If we judge rightly you have no right to complain; if we judge wrong we shall soon be taught by the results, and shall correct our error.
It is evident that if the Morrill tariff fulfills expectations and raises the revenue, British manufacturers suffer nothing, and we suffer nothing, for the revenue is raised here, and trade is not injured.
If the tariff fails to create a revenue we shall be driven to modify or repeal it."

The company addressed him as "governor," which led to Mr. Seward's mentioning that when he was in England he was induced to put his name down with that prefix in a hotel book, and caused a discussion among the waiters as to whether he was the "governor" of a prisoner of a public company.
I hope the great people of England treated Mr. Seward with the attention due to his position, as he would assuredly feel and resent very much any slight on the part of those in high places.
From what he said however, I infer that he was satisfied with the reception he had met in London.
Like most Americans who can afford it, he has been up the Nile.
The weird old stream has great fascinations for the people of the Mississippi — as far, at least, as the first enteract.

div3.head: The United States view of Napoleon's letter to Forey.
div3.p: The Philadelphia Inquirer thinks that no American, can fall to be deeply impressed by the extraordinary character of the letter written by Napoleon to General Forey, on his departure for Mexico."--It adds:

That letter is ostensibly one of instruction from the Sovereign to his General, giving him directions as to his bearing towards the Mexicans, and the policy of the pronuncianfer to be made to that people.
But embodied in the letter are declarations of the Emperor's views concerning the relations of the United States with her sister Republic beyond the Rio. Grande, which could not have been uttered three short years ago without giving deadly offence to the whole American people, nor without exciting demonstrations of resistance throughout the entire length and breadth of the continent.

For more than a generation prior to the outbreak of the rebellion it was the great and unceasing aim of our diplomacy to cherish and support the Monroe doctrine, both at home and abroad.--Every movement of any European power that looked in the slightest degree like an infringement of that cardinal principle of American polities was zealously watched and instantly brought to the notice of the Government of the offending party.
It has, in fact, been the staple of our diplomatic correspondence, with at least one of the great maritime powers of Europe, for more than thirty years. Yet here in this letter of the French Emperor, published with such nonchalance in his official Gazette, the sensitive point of American policy is not only rudely shocked, but the cherished tradition of a continuent, sanctioned by successive generation of statemen, indefiantly act at naught.
Napoleon says in express terms that the real on why he sends his fleets and armies to Mexico, is to establish there, if practicable, a monarchy in the interests of the Latin peace and to check the southward progress of the United States.

If the arms of the United States were not shackled by the gigantic rebellion now waging against her authority, could such declarations be made without firing a demand for war from Maine to the frontiers of Texas?
What then must be thought of the malafides of a sovereign who chooses such a time for such a demonstration?
and what can be thought of his yet fresh expression to the Russian and English Governments of an overruling desire to prevent the effusion of blood in an American war!. Again, there has not been for half a century a period when there was less probability of an attempt to extend the territory of the United States, than since the rebellion of the Cotton States.
It was in their interests that all the agitators for Southern extension were aroused.
Since their defection there has not been a breath of popular desire in favor of Mexican annexation.
That passion was exclusively of Southern growth.
It was the dream of the ambitious conspirators of Secession.
Hence these expressions of the French Emperor take the character of an insult to the United states.

If it were not for the grave and humiliating reflection that Napoleon's letter shows that we have so far fallen in the estimation of the great Powers of Europe that advantage can be taken of our present misfortunes with impunity, our people might look with some satisfaction to the fact that it brings home a merited retribution upon the South.
White Benjamin and Slidell have been showering their blandishments on the "polished courtesy" of their treatment by the French Court, and while they all, from Davis down to Yancey and Knitt, have been reveling in visions of a luxurious, tropical empire, to gratify their ambitious lusts, their wiley and double desiring favorite has advanced his engles to the Rio Grande, there to dispute their progress to the South.
And therefor the present, our people must perforce, be contented to let the matter rest.

div3.head: The release of the Philadelphia editor.
div3.p:
--The release of Boileau, the editor of the Philadelphia Evening Journal, has quite ruined that hero.
His release was obtained on his promise not to publish any "dangerous article" either in the daily or weekly paper of which he was proprietor.
The N. Y. World says:

q.p:
Gen. Scheuck's solitary victory will embalm his name in the annals of political inquisition; and Mr. Boileau may return to his types with the fullest assurance that it will henceforth be morally impossible for him to publish any articles which shall be "dangerous" either to the Government, to its enemies, or to any other human being.
The articles for printing which he was arrested were certainly such in their spirit and language as no paper heartily loyal to the Government would have been likely to publish.
But the injury which they could do was trivial compared with that which Gen. Schenck did in violating the laws of the country and of Pennsylvania by his kidnapping outrage.

div3.p: Mr. Boileau has secured his release by a confession which stamps his former course with the brand and odium of political pusillanimity or falsehood, according as he may be deemed to have controlled a paper which printed articles that he did not approve but feared to exclude, or printed because he got gain for the subservient. In obtaining his release by an act which consigns him, therefore, to the contempt of honest man and the scorn of the loyal, he has (and this is the only view in which his action has more than a petty personal significance) prevented the Government from righting its and enabled it to establish another precedent of lawless despotism.

The Government had no right to punish Mr. Boileau for publishing such articles, except through the law. Mr. Boileau has helped them to flout the cause of liberty and law by consenting to the sacrifices of public rights violated in his person.
It was the violation of these rights alone which gave importance to his case.
He and his paper are alike insignificant.
Gen. Schenck's conduct was not insignificant, and the enlargement of Mr. Boileau leaves all the vital issues of the case untouched, and the portentous wrong of the Government unrepaired and irreparable.

div3.head: Rev. J. R. Graves.
div3.p:
--The examination of Rev. J. R. Graves took place at Hillsboro', N. C., on the 4th, before Judge Manly. George V. Strong appeared for the prosecution, and Hon. Wm. A. Graham for the accused.
He was bound over to the Confederate Court at Richmond, to stand his trial on a charge of treason.

div3.head: Prison Items.
div3.p:
--The following persons were received at Castle Thunder on Saturday and Sunday: B. Riley, Haskin's artillery, desertion, Harry Scean, co &, Battery 4, desertion; Lieut. J. H. Smith, sent from Provost Marshal of Lynchburg, with twenty-four soldiers charged with desertion; W. W. Cannon, co H, 58th N. C, desertion, John King, co C, 14th La, desertion; Robert Taylor, co I, 6th Va, desertion; Thos. Scanlon, drunk; John E McCracy, co F, 15th N. C; P. Holler, co F, 38th N. C.; Wiley Fanikner co K, 54th N. C.; John W. Myrick, co G; 46th N. C.; Knock Jordan, co F, 46th N. C; Avis Jones, co B, 46th N. C.; Jorhua Enscore, co C.; 31 N. C; S. Bett, co C, 33d N. C; Alexander Spaugh co I, 33d N. C; Alex Dunham, co I, 61st N. C.; John Cox, co F, 3d N. C. The soldiers sent to this prison, if not charged with offences demanding trial by court-martial, are sent off every few days in squads and companies to their respective regiments.
There were yesterday between four and six hundred men in the prison, including Yankees.

div3.head: Arrests
div3.p:
--The arrests accomplished by the civil police Saturday and Sunday were few, and for trifling offences.
James Roberts, free negro, was put in the cage for getting drunk and using abusive and threatening language to F. Callahan.
John Morrison and Jessee G. Ingham were put in for lying on the sidewalk while drunk, and after getting sober were discharged.
On Saturday the Provost Marshal's detectives took J. C. Vaughan in custody on the charge of being a substitute agent, and John Collins as a substitute and deserter.

div3.head: Relies of an ancient.
div3.p:
--Last week the caving in of part of a bank near Chimborazo Heights exposed a dozen or two pieces of the backbone of some marine monster of extraordinary size.
One of the joints had become petrified, and weighted about ten pounds. Similar bones were found on digging down Council Chamber Hill and the bank of earth in rear of the Broad Street Trinity Church.

div3.head: The Patent Office.
div3.p:
--The number of applications for patents during the year ending Jan. 1863 was 147; cavoats 64, and of patents issued 75.
Amount of money received, $9,086.98; do on hand, $2,812.62. The patents were distributed among the several States of the Confederacy, as follows: to citizens of Virginia, 20; Mississippi, 10, Alabama, 8; Georgia, 7; Louisiana, 6; Texas, 6; South Carolina, 5; North Carolina, 5; Tennessee, 5; Arkansas, 1; Florida, 1; Kentucky, 1.

div3.head: Ordnance Department of Virginia.
div3.p:
--The issue of arms from this branch of the service, during the last three (mostly in the last two) years, have been as follows: Artillery pieces 331 muskets, 91 455; rifles, 5 631; carbines, 795; musketoons, 375; pistols, 4 438, and swords, 7,520.
These were sufficient for arming 113,486 men.

div3.head: Death of a soldier.
div3.p:
--Moses Overton, a member of Gen. Lee's Body Guard, died yesterday at the hospital of Castle Thunder, of typhoid pneumonia.
He was placed in the castle to be sent to his company.

div3.head: Opening night.
div3.p: --The Marshall Threatre having been rebuilt and fitted up for the accommodation of the public, opens to night with the play of "As You Like It," proceeded by an opening address appropriate to the occasion.

div3.head: Libby Prison.
div3.p:
--There are 509 prisoners in the Libby Prison.
The majority of these are Yankee prisoners, most of whom will be sent to City Point in a few days by flag of truce.

div3.head: The dock.
div3.p: --The water was partially drawn out of the dock yesterday, but no dead bodies were discovered.

div3.head: Court Proceedings.
div3.p:
--There were but few cases before the Mayor to-day.
The most important one was that of Thos. S. Hall, a young man charged with having stolen a set of harness from Edward D. Eacho.
It appeared that after getting possession of the harness he applied to several persons on Franklin street to purchase them, and succeeded in selling finally to Mr. James F. Johnson who bought them for $80, for the use of his stable.
After the theft became known, and Mr. Eacho had reclaimed his property, Hall appeared again on Franklin street and offered to sell a saddle, of which he claimed to be the owner, to a gentleman who knowing the circumstances attending the sale of the harness, took him to Mr. Johnson's stable, who thereupon conducted the enterprising man to the cage.
After hearing the evidence of Mr. Eacho and other witnesses, the Mayor sent the prisoner on to be examined at the regular term of the Alderman's Hustings Court.
The other cases were unimportant consisting of colored persons who had committed sundry petty infractions of the law, and who, after being appropriately admonished were discharged.

Contributions to the Fredericksburg Relief Fund, received by R. R. Howison, Treasurer: Citizens of Charleston. S. C. sent by Fred's Richards Esq. through Hon. W. P. Miles, $1,990; Mrs. Joe Dupuy, Prince Edward co, 20 00; Wm S. Munson, 5 00; Mrs. C. H. R. Charlotte co. 10.00; Powhatan Church, through J. Smith, 235 00; Henry W. Wood and others, Finvanna, 21 00; E. H. M, Augusta, Ga, 20,00; Wm S Panull, Pittsylvania, 50,60; Citizens of Warrenton. N. C. per 1st through Rev. Dr. Hodges, 125,00, Capt Jno Taylor, Culpeper, 50 00, Citizens of Essex through Miss Harriet S. Lewis, 130 00; Wm Harding Heathsville, Va, 100 00; Mrs A. M. C. Harrison, 10 00; Matthew Harrison, Londoun, 100 00; B.B. Noland, 100 00, Jas R. and Thos E. King, of Rosevell, Cobb co, Ga, through Gov Letcher, 250 00, Sussex Church, through Rev. Jas Murray, 15 00; H. Bluntenger, 10 00, L. Waddell, Staunton, 5 00; Rev D. W. Shacks, Amella, 30 00; Peak's Church.
Redford, 213 oo; John M. Woods, Hanover, 6 00; Mrs Jno N. Woods, 10 00; 424 Mississippi regiment, Gen Davis's brigade Goldsboro', N. C. through Rev. T. D. Witherspoon. 755 00; Wm Patterson Smith, Gloucester, 100 00; Mrs Jas A Seddan, Goochland, 100 00, Mrs G. M. Eppinger.
Harrisonburg, 5 00; Rev Thomas D. Bell, do, 5 00; Baptist Church Gooshland, through Rev. H. H. Wyer, 127 25; Chesapeaks Maryland Artillery, Capt W. D. Brown, 215 00, Co B, Richmond Battalion, Capt Louis J. Bossleax, 250 00; Lt Col. H. Harrison, 4th Va. Heavy Artillery, 50 00; Epherns Church, Essex co, 100 50. Wm F. Butler, Bristol.
Tenn. 10 00; Samuel Dovs, Richmond 25 00, Officers and men of Johnson's Artillery, Cpt B. J. Kpps, through Gov Letcher, 165 00; Grace Church Powhatan, and Grub Hill Church.
Ame in, through Rev P. F. Berkeley, 50 00 A Smith, Co C. 19th Va gt 3 00; Mrs. Mary Garrington, Clartsville, 20 00; Mrs r White Lexingtor, 5 00; Trinity Church, Buckingham, (additional) 100 00; N. H. V. C. S. Morizes 5 00; Rev C. S. Hendrick, Baton Rouge, 5 00; Mrs C. M. Shiflett, Palmyra, 5 00; Citizens of Mason, Ga, sent by J. by through Joseph Meyo, Mayor of the city of Richmond, 185 00; Citizens of Chesterfield through Rev Samuel Taylor, 114 00. Wood Church Chesterfield 6 00; Mrs Mary W. qua Prospect, Va. 10 00; Mrs Dr. Allen, dc, 5 00, Mrs. B. W. Wilcon, dc, 5 00, Miss W. Allen, 5 00 Brigade of Gen. W. H. P Lee, through Maj-Gen J Stuart, 00 Citizens of Lynchburg, through.
Wm M. B Esq. 243 45; Edward S gram Albemarle, 00 Capt Jno S. Dancy, Tarboro', C, through Hill & Norfleet, 150 00; Robert H. Fox, Louiss, 10 00; Wm Smith, Meckinburg, 20 00.
A friend, through Rev N. C. Crows, 5 00, Belling W. Harall, 100 00; Judge Jno Robertson, 50 00; Mrs John Robertson, 30 00; John C Stager, 20 00; Churches at Am C. H. New Classgow, en and through Rev. D. C. 200 00; F Mayland Artillery C through Dr. Baylor, (additional) 42 00, Officers at Camp Lee, through Col. J. C. ds

div3.head: Later from the North.
div3.p:
--Northern papers of the 5th; have been received here.
The Herald regards the raising of the blockade, if recognized as a most serious matter.
It says that two months intercourse with Europe would make the South invincible.
It cites various authorities favoring that view of the matter, very decidedly, but expresses its own views dubiously, that the blockade is not raised.
It fears there is some understanding with France and England with regard to this mode of raising the blockade.

The Herald also says that the great armada is waiting favorable winds to leave Beaufort.
It will wipe out the disgrace of Charleston and Galveston.
Four new iron-clads would be sent to sea in a few days.

A telegram from Nashville states that Gen. For had been repulsed at Fort Donelson.
He captured a battery of four guns, but afterwards lost them with about 180 men killed, wounded, and prisoners.
is said to be wounded.
The Herald regards the election of Morgan as Senator from New York as the beginning of the organization of the "great National Convention Union party."

A resolution has been introduced in the New Jersey Legislature declaring that New Jersey would not hold herself responsible for any portion of the debt incurred for emancipating negroes in Missouri or other States.
Gold closed at 157½ Cotton lower.

div3.head: Further from the North.
div3.p:
--New York dates of the 5th and 6th are received.
News of the Charleston fight had been received through Southern papers.
The Times learns authoritatively from Washington that there has been no interruption of the Charleston blockade and that no such assumption will be recognized by the Lincoln Government.--The Times also learns that an attack upon Charleston is momentarily expected, when the blockade will probably be raised in a manner not at all agreeable to the rebels.
The rebels under Forrest and Wheeler were utterly routed at Fort Donelson.

The official dispatches received at Cairo state that they met with considerable loss.
The loss of the Yankees was from forty to fifty.
The rebels have also failed in their demonstration against Island No.10.
Butler has charged himself with $1,088,000 in account with the War Department, as having been received by him from military assessments and confiscations.

The Congressional Committee reported against the admission of Wing from Norfolk district, only 650 votes were polled in a district which has heretofore given ten thousand; therefore it was held no election.

The Vicksburg canal is a failure.
The water is six feet in the cut, but the channel still follows its old course by Vicksburg.
Col. Stuart, chief of McClernand's staff, was killed while reconnoitering near Vicksburg by rebel sharpshooters.

div3.head: From Charleston.
div3.p:
--Robert Bunch, the British Consul, sailed yesterday in the British war steamer Cadmus.
From the officers of that steamer we learn that the results of the late naval engagement were much less substantial than was supposed.
No Yankee vessel was sunk.
The Mercedita was at Port Royal, whither she had been towed in a disabled condition.
The impression among her crew that she was sinking was caused by water rushing into the hold from her boilers, which were perforated by shot.
The Yankee gunboats Quaker City and Keystone State were also struck and badly damaged.

There were several killed and wounded on board each of these three vessels.
The new Ironsides is still off the bar. She goes out to sea every morning, but returns close in every evening, to participate in any night engagement.
The impression prevails among the officers of the blockading squadron that Savannah will be attacked before Charleston will.

The Yankees confess that the iron clad Montask was much injured during the engagement at Genesis Point.
During the latter part of the fight her turret refused to work.

div3.head: Important from the Southwest.
div3.p:
--Deserters are constantly coming in from the enemy at Baton Rouge.
For the past two weeks several have arrived everyday.
All concur in confirming the reported disaffection in Banks's army.
They state that numerous officers have resigned in consequence of the arrival of negro regiments; that the army is completely demoralized, and, in some cases, has reached revolt; and that one regiment is confined in the penitentiary for laying down their arms.

Reliable information states the force at Baton Rouge at 15,000.
There are no indications of an advance.
It is reported that the movement several days since arose from a change of camp.
Banks is stated to have said, "My army has gone to hell — it is useless to deny it. "

A report coming from Baton Rouge represents that the sinking of the U. S. sloop-of war Brooklyn was by the C. S. steamers Alabama. Florida, and Harriet Lane — the Brooklyn having been sent in pursuit of the latter.
The gunboat Essex made her weekly visit on Sunday last, and was fired upon by our pickets.
One Yankee is reported killed.--She shelled our pickets for an hour, but nobody was hurt.
Deserters say that Banks cannot depend upon his army — hence the delay in advancing.

div3.head: The Kentucky Legislature
div3.p:
--A special dispatch to the Advertiser and Register, from McMinnville, 6th inst., states that the Nashville Union, of the 20th, says that the Kentucky Legislature has passed an amendment to the military bill instructing the Kentucky troops not to enforce the President's proclamation.
The vote was 61 yeas, 15 nays.

Administrator's Sale of Eighty-six Acres of Land, in Henrico county, on the Deep-Run Turnpike, at Auction.--As Administrator of John Ford, dec'd, I shall proseed to sell, upon the premises, on Saturday, the 14th day of February, 1863, commencing at 11 o'clock A. M., the tract of Land on which the said John Ford resided, on the Deep-Run Turnpike, in Henrico county, seven miles west of the city of Richmond, and adjoining the lands of Messrs R. J. A. Smith, John W. Alley, and Jas. Shephard.
It contains 8d acres of land, well improved.
The improvements consist of a comfortable Dwelling, with several scams, Harn, Stable, and other necessary out houses together with an excellent orchard of the choicest Fruit Trees.
Terms--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
div3.closer:
John A. Hutcheson,
Late Sheriff of Henrico, co., and as suh
Adm'r of John Ford, dec'd.
Sale by J. M. Taylor & Son, Aucts.
P. S.--The above will be sold at the risk and cost of Jas. H. Ford, who has failed to comply with the terms of sale.
J. A. Hutcheson, Adm'r. fe 3

div3.p:
Administrator's Sale of 5,000 Cords of fine Wood, 100,000 feet of Seasoning Lumber, and one Steam Saw Mill.
Will be sold to the highest bidder, on Thursday, the 12th day of February next, at the Saw Mill lately occupied by Rowland & Shriver, dec'd, about three miles from Cabin Point, Surry co, Va., the following property to wit:

1 Horse and Harness, 2 yoke of Oxen, 1 Steam Saw Mill and Fixtured, Wagons, Carts, Carryings; also, about 100,000 feet of seasoned Lumber, principally inch boards, and from five to seven thousand cords of Pine Wood, 5 Rogie's cross cut Saws, 1 pair large Patect Balances, 10 bales of Hay, and all the Fixtures, too numerous to mention, necessary to carry on a well-kept Saw Mill.
Persons wishing to purchase the wood or lumber, can have every facility for shipping to Richmond or Petersburg by the Norfolk and Petersburg Railroad, which is only a short distance.
Sale to commence at 11 o'clock A. M., when terms will be made known.

div3.head: Administrators' notice.
div3.p:
--Being anxious to settle up the estate of Arson Richards as soon as possible.
I request that all persons indebted to it will at more come forward and settle.
All claims against the estate, if property authenticated, will be paid upon presentation to the undersigned, at Williames, & Co's auction term, on Governor st, one door above Franklin.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 34, page 2.

div3.head: Taking the back Track.
div3.p:
The London Times, a few weeks ago, undertook to defend the institution of slavery upon Scriptural grounds.
This indiscretion so roused the ire of Hector Hall that the Thunderer hastened to undo the mischief it had done by the defence in question.
It now professes to be greatly horrified at President Davis's threat of retaliation for the coldblooded murders that have been perpetrated upon our people, and lectures the South in the following strain:

"The South should remember that they were the first to draw the sword in this quarrel; that they rose against an established Government in the exercise of its legal functions; that they obtained by the agency of traitors in that Government a considerable supply of arms and money; and that that Union which they such to dissolve is as events have proved, the dearest wish of every American heart!!!"

Had we never heard of the London Times before we should certainly have attributed this paragraph to some Yankee, allowed, for the time, to take his meat upon the triped.
We should have believed it impossible for anybody but a scion of that ingenuous nation to have manufactured such a compound of falsehood, malignity, and absurdity.
But we are well acquainted with the Times, and long accustomed to its habit of eating humble pis whenever.
It finds that it has made a false calculation.
The great "Thunderer" is as fearful of expressing an unpopular opinion, and as ready to recant it when once expressed, as any little village sheet that lives upon the smiles and subscriptions of a few score of patrons.
This wholesale recantation of all it has said in nine months takes us not, therefore, by surprise.

The lordly air with which the recantation is made, is, nevertheless, quite edifying.
It takes all the points in dispute, gives the Yankee view of the case, and then boldly asserts that we have all along admitted that Yankee view to be the correct view.
It is very easy to settle a dispute by begging the whole question, if the party upon whom this method of arguing is practiced is willing to submit.
This is not exactly the humor of the South in the present instance.
For example, the South does not "remember that it was the first to draw the sword in this quarrel." No man can "remember" what he never knew.
No man can tax his memory with a truth which never had any existence.
The South does not remember that "it rose against an established Government in the exercise of its legal functions," because it never did any such thing — It withdrew from a Union which sought to oppress it, as it had a perfect right to do — some of the States (Virginia especially) having reserved the right to withdraw at their own pleasure, before joining it, and having been received notwithstanding such reservation.
It rose against a Government which was exercising, not its legal powers, but powers that were not only not granted by the Constitution but were never dreamed of by those who framed that Constitution.
The South did not obtain, by means of traitors in "that Government," arms, money, &c. The letter of ex- President Buchanan settles that matter.
He says the South did not get all the arms they were entitled to. The South do not know that "the Union which they are seeking to dissolve is still the dearest wish of every American heart." They know that if it were so, nobody would be now seeking to dissolve it, taking it for granted, as the Times does, that it still exists, which it has told us a thousand times that it did not. They know that five hundred thousand Americans are in arms to resist it.--They know that fifty battles have been fought to prevent it. They know three hundred thousand lives have been lost in the effort to restore it.

But we are ashamed of treating such absurdities seriously, and should not do it, were it not for the hope of disabusing the minds of all such as still continue to hope for peace through intervention.
The British Government conceives itself to have an interest in letting this quarrel run its course.--Its fears, also, to restrain it. It dare not encounter the enmity of the Yankee nation.
This same Times during the Crimean war, talked magniloquently of "throttling the Northern giant with one hand, and chastising the United States with the other." It holds a different language now.

div3.head: Birds of a Feather.
div3.p:
The Gorilla is steadily cleaning out from his army every officer who has any pretensions to the character of a gentleman, and filling their places with men after his own unseemly pattern.
McClellan, Porter, Burnside, Sumner, Franklin, either of them superior in every quality of intellect and character to the adventurer Joe Hooker, have been thrown overboard, and "fighting Joe," a second edition of Pope, placed in the chief command, to be surrounded by officers as bankrupt in reputation and as reckless of principle as himself.
The contest is being made purely Abolition and destructive in both its aim and agencies, and will be waged with all the malice and fury of demons.
We have no fears of the result, if our leaders exercise the same energy and circumspection which has hitherto characterized their course.
Every step that Lincoln takes in his desperation only plunges him deeper in the mire.
His Abolition proclamation, which he looked to as his last grand card, has already begun to recoil upon himself, and the instruments he is choosing to carry it out, we confidently believe, will hasten the catastrophe of his sinking fortunes.
Let us oppose calmness and courage to this last mad onset of a demented party, and it will be broken into such fragments beyond the power of reconstruction.
The next great defeat of the Abolition hordes will consolidate the whole conservative strength of the North in open and determined resistance to the further prosecution of the war.

div3.head: The Dangers before us.
div3.p:
The tremendous efforts making by the Lincoln despotism East, West, and South, indicate a determination to throw all on the die of battles to be fought within the next three months. If ever there was a moment when the Confederate Government should develope and concentrate all its energies, and when their Generals should at once exercise the greatest circumspection and the highest resolve, now is that hour.
We are almost in sight of port; but, as the coast is more dangerous to the seaman than all the perils of the open sea, and as many a goodly ship has been wrecked upon the breakers which encompass the haven which it was approaching, so we have our greatest hazards to incur as we draw near the long sought harbor of independence, and if we relax for a minute our vigilance, or trust to the transient repose of the treacherous elements by which we are surrounded, may go down and perish just as our hands are almost ready to grasp the glories of the promised land.
Each hour that passes over us now is big with fate.
Better would it have been for us if the Southern star had sunk upon the bloody field of Manassas than that, full orbed and approaching the mid heaven, it should suddenly plunge into obscure darkness.
Soldiers of the South, the Past, the Future, Memory, and Hope-- the fame of the dead and the honor of the living — all call upon you, in this tremendous crisis, to gird up your loins like men, to be as watchful as you are brave as prudent as you are resolved, and, looking to the benignant heaven which has so long inspired and blessed you, to strike wisely and boldly the blows that are to determine for weal or woe the fate of this contest and the destiny of your country.

div3.head: The Yankee Navy.
div3.p:
The haunted supremacy of the Yankees on the water has received of late come crushing blows, and she Confederates have found that, if they had only the means of building up a navy, they would soon be masters of the sea as well as the shore.
If, with limited means, they can accomplish such results as have been lately achieved, what would they do, if they had only a little of the naval opportunities of their enemies.
As to the once dreaded gunboats, they have become simply a laughing stock.
Our very cavalry are capturing them and dragging them along triumphantly at their horses heels.

div3.head: Soldier killed.
div3.p:
--A member of the Baltimore Light Artillery, by the name of Owens, was shot and almost instantly killed in Newmarket, Va., on Sunday night last, by Lieut. Wilhelm, of the same artillery.
Owens had been drinking, was under arrest, and on his way to the guard-house, when he drew a knife and out Lieut. Wilhelm several times, when that officer drew his pistol and shot him, killing him almost instantly.

div3.head: Married.
div3.p: On the 5th inst., by the Rev. C. C. Pearson, Mr. John T. Lipscomb, formerly of Orange C. H. to Miss Margarett A Howard, daughter of S. A. and the late Wm. W. Howard, of this city. *
Abingdon and Mobile papers please copy.

div4.p: At Ashland, on Friday, the 6th inst., Nathaniel, son of Nathaniel and Sarah C. August, aged 4 years 8 months and 7 days.
His funeral will take place from St. James church this (Monday) morning at 11 o'clock. The friends of the family are invited to attend. *
On Sunday morning at half-past 1 o'clock of hooping cough, George Robert, infant son of John W and Harriet E. Crump, aged 1 year 3 months and 18 days.
His funeral will take place from his father's residence this evening, at 4 o'clock. The friends of the family are requested to attend. *
on Friday, February 6th, Mrs. Amanda Margaret, wife of Mr. Robert E. Butler, in the 22d year of her age, leaving a devoted husband and many relatives and friends to mourn their irretrievable loss.

the subject of this notice was kind, gentle, and obliging, possessing a warm and tender heart, feeling for the sufferings of others as if they were her own, and, although not a professor of religion, she cherished a hope of a blissful immortality.
She endeared herself to all who knew her. As a wife, words are inadequate to express how faithful and true was her short life, and with what fortitude and patience she bore her short but painful illness.
Her devotedness none knew so well as her heart-broken husband.
But, alas!
her angel spirit has winged its flight to the God that gave it.

lg.l: There is a torn and quivering place,
Since death has wreathed with ice the brow.
Whose image there death can't efface.
Where once my life's sweet sunshine shone;
But mournfully they seem to speak
Of all that's gone, forever gone."

div4.p: On the same day, Eldridge, infant and only child of Robert E and Amanda M. Butler, aged 2 days.
Richmond Whig and Petersburg Express please copy.

on the 4th inst., at the Chimborazo Hospital, of typhoid fever, Wm. Binns, Co K, 53d Va. Reg't, in the 33d year of his age. He leaves a wife and two children to mourn their loss.
He was a kind and affectionate husband and father.
As a friend he was generous and true, and was beloved by all who knew him.

lg.l: when in this world of grief and pain
we from our friends must sever,
"Tis sweet to look beyond this scene,
Thou didst not sick by slow decay,
Like those that live the longest;
But every tie was wrenched away,
Just when those ties were strongest *

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--For a reliable man, over 45 years of age, and well recommended, a fair price will be paid.
Apply at the store of A Boderer & Co., No. 10 Main street, to-day.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--To go in one of the best companies from this city.
For a reliable man a liberal price will be paid.
A Virginian over 45 preferred.
div3.closer:
Geo. A. Hundley.
182 Broad st. fe 9--5t*

div3.head: Two substitute wanted.
div3.p: --Apply at Columbian Hotel, room No. 13, for three days.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A young Lady, well qualified to teach the usual English branches, French, and Music, to take charge of a school of six or eight pupils in a family in a most desirable and healthy section of country, about 40 miles from Richmond.
One with experience preferred, and none need apply but who can come well recommended.
References exchanged.
Address

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A situation as Bookkeeper.--A young man who has several hours of leisure during the day, is desirous of occupying his time in writing up books and accounts.
He has had several years' experience as an accountant, writes a good hand, and can offer good reference.
Any one wishing to employ him will please address "J. H.," Dispatch Office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--The applicant being a practical mechanic, offers his services as a Master Mechanic of a machine shop or foundry, or Manager of a rolling mill or furnace.
From long experience I am satisfied that I can give general satisfaction.
Address "W," care of William Clark.
Knoxville, Tenn.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--board — By a gentleman and his wife, in a respectable private family.--The object is to get a home — permanent as long as agreeable.
Any one having a comfortable room, etc can find a punctual tenant.
Please address, for three days, through the Post-Office, "R — e," Box 760.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Grinder.--Wanted, at the C S Armory, foot of 5th street and canal, a first-rate Grinder.
One who has been accustomed to gun work preferred.
div3.closer:
W. S. Downer.
Superintendent of Armories. fe 9--6t

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--To hire, immediately, two good Cart Drivers.
Liberal hires will be paid.
Apply at
div3.closer:
C. B. Lipscomb's Coal Office,
14th st., near Mayo's Bridge. fe 9--3t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Warhouse, located on Main, Cary, or one of the cross streets, between 9th and 14th street.
Apply to

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A god Cook, Washer and Ironer, for a small family.
Apply to "W." at

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --A gentleman employed in the Treasury Department has a few leisure hours each day, during which he will be glad to do any Writing which may be offered him. Address "Fides, " Box 216, Post Office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--$25 Reward — Will be paid to any person who will notify the undersigned, through the Dispatch office, of a House which can be rented in a pleasant locality, containing six or eight rooms, furnished or unfurnished, with out-houses.
The above reward is based upon immediate possession and terms to suit.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A competent Miller, to attend a country mill.
Good references will be required.
Address Box 87, or apply at No. 150 Main street, Richmond

div3.head: Important to conscripts.
div3.p:
--The undersigned having been detailed for a short time on recruiting service for the city of Richmond, would respectfully announce, by authority vested in me by order of Major- General G W Smith, the partial suspension of the conscript law, so as to permit conscripts to volunteer in the companies of their own selection in this command, without passing through camps of instruction, and receive the bounty and other benefits provided by law for volunteers.
I urge upon the people of this city the importance of speedily filling up the ranks of our army, in order that the threatened invasion of the State may be repelled.

It is confidently hoped that with the liberal inducements I am authorized to tender to conscripts, a large number will be added to the rolls, and ample means thereby secured for the common defence.
A candid and earnest appeal will be sufficient, it is believed, to awaken you to this high duty which you owe to yourselves and to your country.
I can be found at any time between the hours of 10 A. M. and 9 P. M. in the Military Hall, above the Old Market, corner of 17th and Main streets.

div3.head:
Camp 22d Va., Battalion,
Fields's Brigade, a P. Hill's Division,
February 5th, 1863.
div3.p: Thirty Dollars Reward.--A reward of $30 each will be paid for the arrest and the delivery to me of any one of the following named deserters:
Stepfano Gouovick, an Italian, with very dark complexion, black eyes and hair, and about 5 feet 8 inches high; age, 28 years.
Augustus Kaiser, a German, with light complexion, blue eyes and light hair, about 5 feet 10 inches high, and 22 years of age.

J. R. Phelphs, bails from Lynchburg, says he is a Kentuckian by birth, and was employed on the James River and Kanawha Canal for some time previous to enlistment; complexion dark, dark eyes and hair, 6 feet high, and about 24 years of age.

div3.head:
[Extract]
Headquarters,
Richmond, February 7, 1862.
div3.p: Special orders, No. 27.

IV. Brig-General Winder, commanding Department of Henrico, is charged with the duty of granting Passports beyond the lines of the Confederate army which will be given in such instances, and upon such conditions, as he may deem proper; subject, however, to the discretion of the General in immediate command of the lines through which the applicant desires to pass.
div3.closer:
By command of Maj. Gen. G. W. Smith.
Samuel W. Melton,
Major and A. A. General. fe 9--3t

div3.head: One hundred Dollars Reward.
div3.p:
--Deserted, on the march from Culpeper to Fredericksburg, Va., on or about the 20th of Nov'r, W. P. Brown, a substitute in Co. F, 41st Virginia reg't. Said Brown professes to be a Canadian by birth.
He is about 21 years of age; 5 feet 8 inches high; of delicate appearance; dark complexion and dark hair.
He formerly resided in Richmond.
A reward of $100 will be paid for the apprehension and delivery of the above deserter.
div3.closer:
A. E. Portlock, Capt. Co. F,
41st Va reg't, camp near Fredericksburg, Va. fe 9--3t*

div3.head: Attention, Absentees!--your last Chance.
div3.p:
--Pursuant to orders from Major-Gen G. W. Smith, all Absentees from Capt H B Dickinson's company D, 59th Va reg, are hereby notified to report to camp by 10th February, 1863, and no punishment will be inflicted "except forfeiture of pay" for the time of absence.
Should they not report by the time specified, they will be tried as deserters by the new Court- Martial now in session, and if found guilty punished as such whenever apprehended.

div3.head:
Camp Battery no. 2, Jan. 31, 1863.
last Chance for Absentees.
div3.p:
--Pursuant to orders issued by Major-General Smith, all members of Capt. T. P. Wilkinson's Company, (C,) 10th Battalion Va. Heavy Artillery, now absent, are notified that they must report to camp by the 10th of February, 1863, and no punishment will be inflicted "except the forfeiture of pay" for the time absent.
Should they not report by the time specified they will be considered Deserters, and tried by the new Court-Martial now in session in Richmond, and if found guilty will be shot whenever apprehended.
div3.closer:
John W. Turner,
2d Lt Commanding Co U,
10th Bat Va Heavy Artillery. fe 3--7t*

div3.head:
Camp Battery no. 2,
January 31, 1863.
div3.p: last Chance for Absentees.--Pursuant to orders issued by Major-General G. W. Smith, all members of Company A, 10th Battalion Virginia Volunteers, Heavy Artillery, now absent, are hereby notified that if they report to camp by the 10th day of February no punishment will be inflicted, except the loss of pay for time absent.--Should they not report by the 10th day of February they will be considered deserters, and tried by the new Military Court now in session in Richmond, and if found guilty, will be shot whenever apprehended.
div3.closer:
J. W. Barlow.
Capt. Commd'g Co. A, 10th Batt Va Vols.
Heavy Artillery. fe 2--9t*

div3.head: Ran away.
div3.p:
--From the undersigned, about ten days since, my negro boy George.
For his apprehension and delivery to Mr. Robert Lumpken a reward of $25 will be paid.
George is about 17 or 18 years old, of a dark brown color, tolerably stout built, small head and face, walks slowly and lazily; when spoken to replies slowly with a downcast look; had on, when he left, dark clothes, much worn, and an old straw hat; usually wears a short, shaggy, black over-coat.
He lived the latter part of last year at Mr. H. J. Smith's, near Fairfield, and was again hired there this year but ran off. He is probably secreted by some one in the city, or may be at some of the camps near the city.
If caught beyond the county lines, and delivered here to Mr. Lumpkin, an additional reward of $25 will be paid.
div3.closer:
J. R. Allen,
Corner Main and 11th sts. fe 9--d3t&sw1t

div3.head: Runaway in jail.
div3.p:
--Was committed to the jail of Henrico county, as a runaway, a negro boy named Jim, as the property of John Montgomery, of the county of York, Va. The said boy is about 18 years old; 5 feet 7 inches high, with brown skin; had on when committed a full suit of gray Virginia clothing.
The owner of said boy is requested to come forward, prove property, pay charges, and take him away, or he will be dealt with as the law directs.

closer.signed: Geo. D. Pleasants, S. H. C.

div3.head: Land, negroes, &C., for Sale.
div3.p:
--The undersigned are authorized to sell a large and well-improved Farm, lying in a desirable section, very near to the James River Canal, and within a convenient distance of Richmond.
It produces fine tobacco, and all other staple crops.
The improvements are good.
If desired the Slaves and Stock would be sold with the land.
A reasonable price will be taken for all the property.
Apply to
div3.closer:
W. & W. S. Peters,
Com'n Merchants, 12th st, South of Cary,
Richmond Va. ja 27--d&sw2w

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--A Woman, of excellent character, as Cook in a private family.
She is without encumbrance.
Also, a Girl, for Dining-room Servant or Nurse, who is honest and can be recommended in every respect.
Call on Grace st., two doors above Adams.

div3.head: Negroes for hire.
div3.p:
--We still have for hire several good Cooks, Washers, and Ironers, and a good lot of House Girls and Boys.
Also, a superior Dining room Servant, and several Women with children, whom we would put out for their victuals and clothes.
We have also a good coarse Shoemaker.
For terms, &c., apply to
div3.closer:
Clopton & Lyne,
Corner Wall and Franklin sts. fe 7--2t

div3.p: We have for private sale a very likely Chambermaid, about 18 years of age. Apply to

div3.head:
By Hill, Dickinson & Co., Auct's.
Commissioner's Sale of two negroes.
div3.p: --Under a decree of the County Court of Henrico, I will sell on Monday, 9th of Feb'y, 1863, at 10 o'clock, at the auction house of Hill, Dickinson & Co, a Negro Woman and Boy.
